page.title: 10TRANSPORT (1)
page.content: The Settle to Carlisle railway, which passes through Stainforth and Langcliffe was one of the outstanding engineering feats of the Victorian Age. It reaches an elevation of 1,169 feet between the north-south valleys of the Ribble and the Eden; the Ribblehead Viaduct, now sadly in need of repair (but still carrying trains) is one of the main features of the line, together with the Blea Moor tunnel and the 'Long Drag' up from Settle past Ribblehead. It was completed in May, 1876, having taken six and a half years to complete at a cost of nearly Â£3.5 million and hundreds of lives of the navvies who worked on the line. The railway is now threatened with closure, though there is a very active group which co-ordinates pressure to keep it open.
